FuncDef:
The ds-lite bind instance command binds a DS-Lite instance to a traffic behavior.
The undo ds-lite command deletes the binding between a DS-Lite instance and a traffic behavior.
By default, a DS-Lite instance is bound to no traffic behavior.

ParaDef.Info:
Specifies the name of a DS-Lite instance.
The value is a string of 1 to 31 case-sensitive characters, spaces not supported. When double quotation marks are used around the string, spaces are allowed in the string.

ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
Traffic distribution policies must be defined to direct traffic to a service board for DS-Lite processing. The configuration involves defining ACL rules, traffic classifiers, traffic behaviors, and traffic distribution policies and applying the traffic distribution policies. To bind a DS-Lite instance to a traffic behavior, run the ds-lite bind instance command.
Prerequisites
ACL rules have been configured to match user traffic to be processed by DS-Lite. Traffic classifiers have also been configured.
Follow-up Procedure
Bind the traffic classifier with the traffic behavior in a traffic distribution policy and apply the traffic distribution policy to an interface or globally.
Precautions
In the traffic behavior view, the DS-Lite redirection is mutually exclusive with redirection actions (including the deny action, NAT44 traffic distribution, NAT64 traffic distribution, DNS redirection action, HTTP redirection action, and redirect action, and redirect-CPU action).
Biding a DS-Lite instance to a traffic behavior is mutually exclusive with mirroring.
If the destination address of a packet matches both an ACL rule and a FIB entry, the ACL rule takes precedence over the FIB entry for traffic diversion. For example, a DS-Lite IPv6 prefix 2001:db8::1/96 is defined for DS-Lite instance A, and the prefix matches ACL1 which is bound to DS-Lite instance B. Packets destined for 2001:db8::1/96 are preferentially matched against ACL1 and assigned to DS-Lite instance B instead of DS-Lite instance A. As a result, DS-Lite processing fails to be performed for the packets.
